claim: If video recordings of lectures are provided, nothing in particular happens to class attendance.

supporting.text: Studies have shown that providing video recordings of lectures does not significantly impact in-person attendance, as students still value live interaction and immediate feedback from instructors.

attacks.text: Studies have shown that providing video recordings of lectures does not significantly impact in-person attendance, as students still value live interaction and immediate feedback from instructors.

Some studies indicate that when video recordings are available, a subset of students (especially those with scheduling conflicts) may skip in-person lectures, leading to a measurable decline in attendance.
The decline in attendance due to video recordings is often temporary, as students who initially skip realize they perform better with live participation and return to attending in person.
Instructors report that students who rely solely on recordings often miss nuanced explanations and spontaneous discussions that occur in live lectures, which are not fully captured in recordings.
Advanced students or those revisiting material may benefit more from recordings, as they can pause and rewatch complex sections without needing live attendance.

supporting.text: Empirical data from universities indicate that lecture video availability has minimal effect on attendance rates, as many students prefer structured learning environments.

attacks.text: Empirical data from universities indicate that lecture video availability has minimal effect on attendance rates, as many students prefer structured learning environments.

Studies show that in some courses, particularly those with large enrollments, attendance drops significantly when lecture recordings are available, as students prioritize flexibility over in-person attendance.

The preference for structured learning environments is often overstated, as surveys indicate that many students attend lectures primarily due to participation grades or peer pressure, not genuine preference.
The empirical data cited may be outdated or limited to specific disciplines, ignoring recent trends where students increasingly rely on recorded lectures for self-paced learning.
Even in self-paced learning scenarios, students often supplement recorded lectures with in-person attendance for interactive components like Q&A or group work, maintaining overall attendance levels.

supporting.text: Research in educational psychology suggests that students who attend lectures in person perform better academically, regardless of video availability, which discourages absenteeism.

attacks.text: Research in educational psychology suggests that students who attend lectures in person perform better academically, regardless of video availability, which discourages absenteeism.
Studies show that many students prefer recorded lectures for flexibility, leading to higher engagement with material despite lower physical attendance.
In-person attendance fosters direct interaction and immediate feedback, which recorded lectures cannot replicate, reinforcing the value of physical presence.
Some institutions report no significant change in attendance patterns after introducing lecture recordings, suggesting minimal impact on student behavior.
The absence of attendance decline may be due to self-selection bias, where only motivated students opt for recordings without affecting overall attendance.

supporting.text: Institutional policies often require attendance for participation grades or discussions, making video recordings a supplementary resource rather than a replacement for class presence.

attacks.text: Institutional policies often require attendance for participation grades or discussions, making video recordings a supplementary resource rather than a replacement for class presence.
Many institutions do not enforce mandatory attendance policies, allowing students to rely solely on video recordings without penalty.
Even in institutions without strict attendance policies, in-person interaction and spontaneous discussions often provide learning benefits that recordings cannot replicate.
Students may perceive video recordings as sufficient substitutes for attendance, leading to lower in-person participation even when not explicitly penalized.
Studies show that students who attend lectures in person retain information better and engage more actively than those who rely solely on recordings.

supporting.text: Surveys reveal that students use lecture videos primarily for review, not as a substitute for attending class, which maintains stable attendance levels.

attacks.text: Surveys reveal that students use lecture videos primarily for review, not as a substitute for attending class, which maintains stable attendance levels.
Studies show that when lecture recordings are available, some students skip classes, assuming they can catch up later, leading to a decline in attendance.
Even if some students skip, many still attend due to interactive elements like Q&A, which are not replicable in recordings, balancing overall attendance.
Lecture recordings may reduce attendance because students prioritize flexibility, especially when balancing work or other commitments.
Institutions that enforce mandatory attendance policies alongside recordings see no drop, indicating that policy, not recordings, affects attendance.

supporting.text: The social and collaborative aspects of in-person lectures, such as peer interaction and group activities, are not replicated by videos, sustaining attendance demand.

attacks.text: The social and collaborative aspects of in-person lectures, such as peer interaction and group activities, are not replicated by videos, sustaining attendance demand.
Many students prioritize convenience and flexibility over social interaction, leading them to skip in-person lectures when videos are available.
Even if some students skip lectures for convenience, others still value in-person interaction, maintaining partial attendance demand.
Online platforms and discussion forums can effectively replicate peer interaction and collaboration, reducing the need for in-person attendance.
Virtual interactions lack the spontaneity and depth of face-to-face communication, making them an imperfect substitute.
